title: Do It Better: Creative Production with AI

rawLines.text: [Music]
What are the biggest misconceptions
marketing leaders have about AI creative
production and how should they rethink
their approach to stay competitive?
There are two misconceptions that I
usually see. Uh the first is that people
assume AI will turn out creatives and
content ready to go without any sort of
human input and that they think AI
replaces creativity entirely. If you
think about AI as a great way to handle
repetitive tasks, then all of a sudden
you free yourself from a lot of tedious
uh creation and then you can focus your
energy on strategy, on storytelling and
so on. Another misconception is that
adopting AI means you will lose brand
voice and you will lose your
storytelling and how cohesive you are.
But in fact the re the best AI solutions
out there should enhance uh your brand
guidelines not overwrite them. The last
thing I've seen is that some marketers
still choose between quantity or quality
and they see AI as a quantity um helper
but not a quality helper. And again the
market I think will reward marketers who
are aggressive with testing. So my
advice is to use AI as a partner and not
as an autopilot solution. Let it handle
all of the tedious stuff so your teams
can actually invest more time on
creativity on building compelling
stories and really building memorable
brand experiences for users.
Misconceptions are that that people
think it's just plug and play. You don't
have to be really creative, but you will
lose all the control. You'll get crazy
brand six-finger ads and it's really a
quantity play. But that's not the case.
So these kind of misconceptions given,
how do you see AI revolutionizing uh ad
creation and optimization? One thing
that I'm really excited about is the
level of personalization that we can
reach at scale. And this has never been
done in videos before. If you think
about it, my dad and I drive the same
car, but will we appeal to the same ad
for the car? It's very unlikely. So
marketers have to stop thinking about
what is the perfect ad and start
thinking about what set of ads and what
set of variations will deliver on brand
lift or performance whatever they're
after. And this has been done with
static images a while back and people
optimize their creatives
programmatically. But it's now possible
to deliver on that same promise in
videos which is the biggest consumed
media out there. Um, so that's the the
topic we're the most excited about, how
how you're able to personalize uh videos
to appeal to every single user and not
have to choose one direction for your
entire company. And so this
personalization comes from the fact that
it's easier and faster to produce ads
through AI. And because it's easier,
cheaper, faster, more effective, that
allows you to have more creatives. and
more creatives allows you to be more
personalized for different segments. And
not only that, if you think about the
UGC market, in the past, if you wanted
to AB test content with UGC, you would
have to be very meticulous because if
you hired an actor to record a video and
you wanted 3 weeks later to just change
some item of that video, you would need
to get the same actor in the same outfit
with the same hairstyle, with the same
level of energy, and maybe adapt the
messaging. uh that's incredibly hard to
do and most marketers stopped doing it
or never did it in the first place. And
so certainly it allows you to have a
clear control over what set of variables
you want to play with in your video and
keep everything else the same. And that
that's a big one because it allows you
sort of a management of the creatives
even after the creatives have been done
by going back to them, modifying,
changing things that that you think
could be done better without actually
increasing your production costs. That's
exactly right. And and that's that's one
of the things that we see customers
realizing more and more. In the past, it
was shoot it and forget it. And now it's
a continuous cycle where they start
producing. There's a baseline and then
they add on to that baseline with uh
more content, different content,
altering existing content and it's a
continuous cycle to get a stream of
creatives that makes sense for their
audience.
And let's talk about brands because in a
podcast gamecraft podcast that they were
talking about AI and they brought this
interesting kind of bare and bull case
of AI the bull case of AI they were
saying that you would be able to make
games basically through prompts. Uh and
then the the bare case which they
consider to be more likely is that the
market gets flooded with subpar titles
that are essentially taking away space
from mediocre titles. Uh but they're at
the same time boosting the big IP games.
So everything gets flooded that is mid
to low. But the the games with those
brands, they're known to be of higher
quality and they just get more demand
because people know that they're going
to be as promised. And so when we take
this analogy into brands uh in creatives
in marketing, do you think this kind of
same thing could happen where the market
just gets flooded with similar ads as
we've actually been seeing and then the
branded ads, somebody who's using
Monopoly or Assassin's Creed or Call of
Duty kind of stands out from the mass
produced with AI? What's your take? I
love this question because it actually
is something we see even outside of
gaming. Even if you think of my LinkedIn
posts, um, I'm not a big-time
influencer, but I do have an audience.
AI helps me to create that content
faster, but really the reason why it's
seen by my audience is that I've built
somewhat of a brand, and that's going to
win in the long term for companies that
are strong on IP. Of course, it doesn't
mean that small companies won't be able
to compete. It kind of levels the
playing field on the creative side, but
if you're seeing a Monopoly Go ad, of
course, you're going to resonate with
that ad a lot more if that brings up
childhood memories. They have an edge uh
that no amount of creatives will be able
to outperform.
And so we do think it levels the playing
field. But
ultimately even at those companies there
are marketers that resist or either
resist change or treat AI like a magic
wand rather than a tool. And those teams
will be losers of the you know marketing
performance game. And if they're not
ready to put in the effort, if not ready
to u go out of their comfort zone and
kind of build that process over time and
iterating over their integration with AI
or leveraging AI in different
ways. We like to think of it as losers
wait for AI to solve everything and
winners leverage AI to elevate human
creativity and understand that it's a
process to get there.
This podcast is brought to you by Apps
Flyier. In today's digital world,
understanding your app's journey from
discovery to download is more than just
insightful. It's essential. Enter
Appslier, the leader in mobile
attribution and marketing analytics that

deep into datadriven insights that

from and how they'll interact with your
app. AppSlire, where your app's
potential meets performance.
But if you would have to um on a short
term make a call, do you think that
brands are net gainers of the AI
marketing revolution or losers?
Winners 100%.
only because their their brand power is
so strong and if they use AI to amplify
that that's an amazing result they're
going to see. I liked Brian Chesky
Airbnb CEO's take on brand marketing in
general. Hayes words were that brand
marketing is like the equivalent of
lighting up a room with a big chandelier
and performance marketing is um having
lasers uh pointed at a very specific
direction. So if you wanted to light up
a room, you wouldn't use a bunch of, you
know, lasers. You would probably use a
chandelier. That's a very efficient way
to light up the room. And brands have
that chandelier power that no smalltime
company has. And so the small time
company has to go with the laser
strategy. And so if the brands use a
chandelier to light up the room and then
they use lasers whenever they need to,
they can use AI to actually light up the
room a lot faster and shine in the world
of gaming a lot faster.
Well, let's talk about volume then. So
AI tools enable marketers to, as you
said, scale production and scale
personalization by just being able to
produce more. So what's the right
balance between volume and creative
quality?
I think the balance lies in setting
clear creative guard rails. When you
build a set of creatives, whether it's
brain voice or visual standards or
narrative style, AI can handle a lot of
the mechanical tasks like editing. uh
like I previously
mentioned, but humans still need to
ensure each piece of content feels
authentic, feels on brand, and that's
the sweet spot. Um I like to think of it
as if you look at a set of videos that
you produce with
AI, ask yourself, are we sharing a
compelling story uh to the end user? And
is that story cohesive? Does it make
sense as a whole? If so, it's game on
and you can scale. Uh if not, you're
probably a little bit too much on the uh
performance side and probably a little
too focused on the testing rather than
the chandelier analogy I shared earlier,
which is absolutely fine for companies
that do not have a brand. They don't
have a choice. So then it's no longer if
you don't have a monopoly, go brand, go
performance and go very aggressive on
testing. And I don't think there should
be any limits there. Um, but if you do
have a brand you want to leverage and
keep and entertain and grow, then uh I
think setting up clear creative
guardrails for the team ensures that
they're able to evaluate the content and
be sure that they thumbs up the content
that's actually cohesive with the brand
story. So if you're building a brand, of
course, have brand guidelines and use
those brand guidelines in your creative
production. Actually pretty simple to
integrate with your AI production tools.
If you don't have it, go buck wild.
There's no amount of volume that is too
much. Is that what you're saying?
Correct. And and we see across the board
companies spending a little bit of money
on marketing, the smaller companies um
who spend 20k a month, 50k a month, 100k
a month, small media budgets um in in
the grand scheme of things. and they
actually we see them producing a lot
more creatives uh than some of the
bigger companies out there because they
understand well if I don't have a brand
I have to let the market figure out what
creative is going to perform for me and
what's going to drive my uh user
adoption and so we see them producing on
average two to three times more in
creative content although they're
spending you know 10 times less 100
times less a thousand times less than
some of these marketers
You've talked about volume and you
talked about personalization. Those two
things together with AB testing kind of
don't compute in my head. Do you think
that in traditional like we will be
moving away from this traditional AB
testing more towards AIdriven dynamic
optimization where you're finding
different segments and showing them
different creatives rather than finding
that hero creative? We absolutely think
the the AB testing where you define a
set of two variables and you kind of
test you know blue or red for that
button uh or messaging on a very simple
item that specifically I believe many
companies already moved away from um the
early adopters at the very
least. There's actually a lot less value
in an AB testing methodology now versus
5 years ago. Um there there's many
different reasons, but
essentially one reason is what we
mentioned earlier. There's not a one
perfect creative for the entire
audience. And so when you think about AB
testing, that gives you one path to one
specific audience, but really what you
want is a stream of creatives that are
relevant for a specific audience.
The other thing
is the richness of data in video content
which is now the most consumed media is
so much higher than in images that if
you wanted to properly AB test you would
have to isolate the most important
variables. You would have to test many
different combinations of those
variables and then you do this for every
set of variable you have available. This
is you potentially tens of thousands of
videos to produce every single month.
And no matter how excited we are about
early adopters and how we are about uh
performance marketers testing a lot of
content, we do have a few customers who
are at that scale. But we only have a
few customers who are producing, you
know, at that level. Other than that,
it's very hard to do. So instead we
think of it
as let's let the creative win for a
specific uh audience and that creative
stream will have a journey that evolves
over time through the variables of the
video for a given audience. If one day
it's a 20-year-old male on the video
that performs and then over time maybe
they realize that it's not a 20-year-old
male but a a 25-year-old female then
they will evolve that set of creatives
for a particular audience they want to
attract. Uh so so it's no longer an AB
test, but rather what are the variables
you want to play with? And once you
define your stream of creatives, what
are the variables you want to actually
deploy to attract a specific type of
user? That's really key here. I've I've
used the analogy, at least when we're
talking about AB testing in games. I use
the analogy of of ice cream. So I'm I'm
a father of two, so that's on the menu
all the time. And it's almost like you
have the the chocolate, the strawberry,
and vanilla, and you're doing the test
and you're figuring out which ice cream
is the most like. Well, vanilla is
preferred by 55% of the kids. So,
everybody gets vanilla, but there's 45%
who actually would have preferred
chocolate. And so, with this
personalization approach, essentially,
what you're saying is find the ones that
like their type of ice cream and serve
them that ice cream. And that way you
will have a broader audience because
everybody is getting what they actually
want rather than taking what the
majority wants. I absolutely love this
analogy. I've never heard this analogy
before. I will absolutely reuse it and
steal it for myself and quote you when I
do. Web stores. You've seen what good
looks like, but have you seen great? App
charge is the direct to consumer
platform backed by the likes of

for top studios, optimizing every

offers custommade design,
industry-leading monetization features,
in-game payments SDK, and more. 70% of

they're doing it with Appcharge. Learn
more at appcharge.com.
Well, you're you're welcome. Uh well the
the other part about this is is of
course the the predictive analytics. How
do you think marketing leaders can
ensure that they're using the right
insights in the most effective way
rather than just accumulating insane
amount of data? You can only optimize
what you measure or what you use.
And what I encourage uh companies to do
is implementing predictive analytics
with the understanding that you're going
to pay a lot of money. You're going to
spend a lot of time and it's not going
to work.
And the reason I say it's not going to
work is there's really a missing word
here. It's in the beginning. And that's
okay. It's an iterative cycle. It's not
a plugandplay solution that kind of
works out of the box. Companies
implementing predictive analytics and
expecting a great result. It's the
equivalent of um Picasso drawing their
first painting and assuming that's going
to be a big masterpiece. any sort of
famous artist has gone through a process
of iteration to get to where they are
now. And people look at obviously the
the final result that we all know, but
they don't see the struggle and they
don't see the iterations, the many
different cycles it took to get there.
And so for predictive analytics, it's
the exact same thing. When you have a
ton of data, you're just sitting on it.
If your mindset is let me try to see if
I can, you know, help predict the next
event or help predict what I should do
or how we should paint a certain uh
picture in the video. You have to
iterate. You optimize. You improve your
models. You give it more data or you
structure the data differently which
usually helps a lot more than just more
data. You course correct and you repeat.
And marketers that start doing that are
on a path to getting there. Some of them
are getting very fast to their end
result. Some of them need a little bit
more time. But I'll tell you one thing,
I can guarantee you will never find
success with predictive modeling if you
never went past the initial failure.
So accumulate a lot of data and don't be
afraid of it and iterate with the data.
Um and teach your models to handle it.
Should you continue al always with uh
getting as much data as possible or can
you kind of tone it down and focus on
the type of data you need? Well, that's
the thing. Once you start that course
correction, once you start the iterative
process, you know what data matters more
and you know how to structure your data.
So all of a sudden you go from a garbage
of data to a very structured database
where you know exactly why you're
collecting that data point and you know
which items are not useful and then you
can remove that. If I tell any data
science team that we're going to remove
any data they're going to go crazy but
at a high level that's what you would
want to do. In reality you should really
keep all the data you have because one
day it may be useful and you don't know
it yet. Uh but if you want a more
pragmatic approach and a kind of faster
results, that's that's one way to go
about it. One thing that's important is
for execs to actually set a correct
timeline. And if you're thinking about
short-term, if you're thinking about the
next quarter or the next month, then no
amount of data will help you get there.
And so it's up to the leaders of the
company to set up a timeline where they
actually share with the team, hey, we
have the next three years where we're
going to get we want to get this right.
It's all eyes on the exec team to set
that expectation correctly because then
that gives the breathing room for the
teams to actually implement the correct
strategy and to leverage predictive
analytics the right way. So there seems
to be somewhat of a change of what is
expected from a marketing leadership.
Data fluency is becoming one of the
competences that is required from from
the uh marketing leaders. So looking

brief AI models uh very effectively plus

at integrating tools third party tools
into actionable workflows.
um it doesn't negate you know the

storytelling those remain irreplaceable
but I feel like there will be more and
more AI ethicist or an AI governance

very fast and we already see it at
companies.

it's not a mutually exclusive. It's not

way to replace human creativity or does
it enhance it? I know you're going to
say it is going to enhance it, but tell
me how it's going to enhance it.
Yeah, it's all about the time you have
to do the things you'd love doing and
where you have value. So certainly I'm a
big believer that AI is enhancing human
creativity, not replacing it. Um doing a
few things. First, it acts as a as a
really a partner in your thought
process. I use it all the time to kind

know, breaking down my ideas and why is
it a good idea, why is it a bad idea,
analyze it, um, can you help me tweak

excited about on the day-to-day. So, one
is using AI as a as a partner. I want to
make sure that essentially AI helps me
get rid of the tasks that drain me and
allows me to spend more time in what we
call a genius zone. to where you are in
a flow state, you truly understand what
you're doing, you see a clear vision for
ahead and you execute on that. So if you
buy yourself time to do that, that's the
most important and that's the most
valuable asset you can gain back. Jeff
Bezos famously said his job is
essentially making six good decisions
per year. And the reason he spent his
time the way he did when he was CEO at
Amazon was he needs to make sure he has
all the context and he has the right
level of energy to make those six
decisions. Six decisions is all it takes
per year for him to to consider his job
successful. And so we're all Jeff Bezos
in a way. And I want to make sure that
AI helps us get there faster uh by
having more context about us about what
we do about how we do things. So, um, so
those are the two ways that we really
see AI enhancing human creativity
and I'm 100% convinced that it's a tool
that we should use and it's a partner.
